intro: Eriocaulon sikokianum var. piliphorum, commonly known as the Piliphor pilose sedge, is a flowering plant belonging to the family Cyperaceae. It is characterized by its dense, grass-like foliage and small, inconspicuous flowers that are typically clustered in spikelets. The plant is native to tropical and subtropical regions, where it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. Its leaves are usually narrow and slightly hairy, contributing to its distinctive appearance. This variety is often found in wetlands and along the edges of freshwater bodies, where it plays a role in stabilizing soil and supporting local biodiversity.
